This course sets the foundation for the thinking and practice of interior architecture as a distinctive idea and research-led field of design inquiry and practice. The Design component introduces students to the processes, materiality and elements of interior architecture. Emphasis is placed on an expansive approach to spatial enquiry, underpinned by thoughtful and self-reflective research. This course is educationally sequenced alongside all other year one session one BIA (Hons) courses.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"13d3612bdb21fc50be4672f5f396196d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Design Presentation (Individual summative)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Assessment is in the form of a formal presentation (visual and verbal) of the final design.
At a minimum this will include:
- Site plan 
- Scaled Plans and Sections

- Perspectives

- Materials palette

- Supporting process work to communicate the design development process

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"53d3612bdb21fc50be4672f5f396196f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5bd3612bdb21fc50be4672f5f396196e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9bd3612bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961976","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Creative Research + Concept design proposal (Individual summative)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Assessment is in the form of a Conceptual design presentation communicating the project design intent, and process of creative research to date. This includes a series of:

_scaled models

_drawings

_supporting precedent studies

_other process artefact created throughout studio Weeks 1-4

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"53d3612bdb21fc50be4672f5f396196f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"53d3612bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961970","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5bd3612bdb21fc50be4672f5f396196f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9fd3612bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961971","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Engagement Portfolio (Individual formative)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This is a pass/ fail assessment of a series of process work artifacts created through set tasks to be completed during studio tutorial time. Tasks will be spread out across the duration of the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"53d3612bdb21fc50be4672f5f396196f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"53d3612bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961970","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5bd3612bdb21fc50be4672f5f396196e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d3d3612bdb21fc50be4672f5f396197a","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/INTA1000.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

The Design component introduces students to the processes, materiality and elements of interior architecture. Emphasis is placed on an expansive approach to spatial enquiry, underpinned by thoughtful and self-reflective research. This course is educationally sequenced alongside all other year one session one BIA (Hons) courses.

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"INTA1002 - Interior Architecture Composition 2","description":"

This course builds on capabilities and skills from composition 1 to develop a further range of communication skills specific to interior architecture. Students will explore intermediate analogue and digital representations; and develop specialised model making techniques within a workshop context. Emphasis will be placed on an iterative approach to making as a means of spatial exploration, research and articulation of interior environments. This course is educationally sequenced alongside all other year one session two BIA (Hons) courses.

A final curated graphic layout of idea-led 2D drawings and 3D models, both digital and analogue developed from Assessment 2 with verbal presentation.

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"INTA1003 - Interior Architecture Composition 3","description":"

The course extends the range of Interior architectural capabilities from composition 1 & 2. A further range of advanced techniques and applications for representing spatial atmosphere and effect, including analogue drawing, digital representation and layout along with advanced model making is presented in this course. Workshops will also provide students with public speaking and communications tools of relevance to the practice of interior architecture. This course is educationally sequenced alongside all other year two session one BIA (Hons) courses.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"58e3a12bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961994","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"EP tasks: modelling","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

The Engagement Portfolio consists of process tasks that will help develop, and directly contribute to, your
Assessments. The process work produced from the tasks can also be used in your Assessments. The EP
(Engagement Portfolio) tasks are structured to be completed before class, in class and after class to foster
iterative and reflective design practice. The tasks comprise of independent learning, peer to peer learning and
tutor guided learning to build skills in individual, collaborative and directed practice to best serve you as
graduates.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d4e3a12bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d4e3a12bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"dce3a12bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961996","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9ce3a12bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961998","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"EP tasks: rendering","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

The Engagement Portfolio consists of process tasks that will help develop, and directly contribute to, your Assessments. The process work produced from the tasks can also be used in your Assessments. The EP (Engagement Portfolio) tasks are structured to be completed before class, in class and after class to foster iterative and reflective design practice. The tasks comprise independent learning, peer to peer learning and tutor guided learning to build skills in individual, collaborative and directed practice to best serve you as graduates.

Students are to realise their design through a cohesive and rounded package of visualisation of
renders, architectural diagrams, drawings and animation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d4e3a12bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d4e3a12bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"dce3a12bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961996","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e0e3a12bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619a2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Package","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are to storyboard their ideas and conceptual approach to the design they are creating.
The example above is Bernard Tschumi relating the human body and anthropomorphic movement of
a person tumbling which is translated directly to the architectural response in 3D form.

contentlets.keywords: interior architecture,communications skills,digital representation,model making,public speaking
contentlets.description: The course extends the range of Interior architectural capabilities from composition 1 & 2. A further range of advanced techniques and applications for representing spatial atmosphere and effect, including analogue drawing, digital representation and layout along with advanced model making is presented in this course. Workshops will also provide students with public speaking and communications tools of relevance to the practice of interior architecture. This course is educationally sequenced alongside all other year two session one BIA (Hons) courses.
contentlets.title: Interior Architecture Composition 3

This course focuses on the articulation of design ideas through research, thinking, drawing and making, practices.


The Design component introduces students to languages and elements of Interior Architectural and spatial
enclosure and definition, including issues of materiality, assemblage and composition, human scale and form, in
relation to simple forms of Interior Architectural occupation.


This course is educationally sequenced alongside all other year one session two I-A (Hons) courses.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"18acb8c8db123050595850d8f49619af","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"In class workshops","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"0","description":"

A series of small, in-class tasks generating quick spatial responses to the project brief using hand drawing, diagrams and model-making alongside informal verbal presentation and peer review.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"50acb8c8db123050595850d8f49619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"50acb8c8db123050595850d8f49619b2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"54acb8c8db123050595850d8f49619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"58acb8c8db123050595850d8f49619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"58acb8c8db123050595850d8f49619b2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"24acb8c8db123050595850d8f49619e2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Resolution","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

Final presentation of an idea -led design proposal showing resolution of macro through micro detail in terms of volume, threshold, sequence, materiality, light and detail, in response to site, user and program, without verbal presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"50acb8c8db123050595850d8f49619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"50acb8c8db123050595850d8f49619b2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"54acb8c8db123050595850d8f49619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"58acb8c8db123050595850d8f49619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"58acb8c8db123050595850d8f49619b2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"28acb8c8db123050595850d8f49619db","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Engagement Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

A curated collection of preliminary design research and ideas, in response to the project brief, that refines and expands upon in-class workshops, with verbal presentation.

Interim presentation of a research-led design proposal focused on volume, threshold and sequence in response to site, user and program, with verbal presentation.

relation to simple forms of Interior Architectural occupation.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"INTA2001 - Interior Architecture Technics 1","description":"

The course sets the foundation for the craft and discipline of interior architecture through a broader introduction to the people, processes, principles and primary building elements surrounding built space. Core considerations include the role of the interior architect, the design, documentation and construction processes; the informants of design making including aesthetics, functionality and sustainability; structural principles and basic constructional assemblies. Emphasis is on the material, constructional and structural idea of structure, substrate and skin through studio based exercises and precedent studies.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ade3e12bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619f2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project B","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Project B introduces students to basic sustainable design concepts and will allow them to recognise the
importance of sustainable design in interior architecture. Students will be able to identify the major
sustainability considerations in the design process and illustrate their understanding of the role of
sustainable design to the practice of interior architecture.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e9e3e12bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619f4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"65e3e12bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619f8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project A","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Project A is an individual task that introduces students to the major constructional systems and primary
building components used in the formation of interior space. Students will demonstrate their ability to
identify the various components in terms of assembly, materiality of structure, substrate and skin.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e9e3e12bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619f3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6de3e12bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619f5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project C","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Project C requires student to demonstrate basic documentation skills specific to the practice of interior
architecture this will be achieved by the production of a hand drafted drawing set based on the study of a
precedent. This project is in 2 parts; Part 1, 25%, and Part 2, 25%. Total weighting of project= 50%

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e1e3e12bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619f4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6de3e12bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619fa","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/INTA2001.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Core considerations include the role of the interior architect, the design, documentation and construction processes; the informants of design making including aesthetics, functionality and sustainability; structural principles and basic constructional assemblies. Emphasis is on the material, constructional and structural idea of structure, substrate and skin through studio based exercises and precedent studies.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"INTA2002 - Interior Architecture Technics 2","description":"

This course focuses on the basic constructional assembly systems and components of interior architectural
building elements. Core considerations include structure, substrate and skin explored in reference to an
introduction to materiality from macro elements to joinery items; building on documentation techniques as a
means of technical communication to industry professionals and the role of the builder versus the role of the
interior architect and the coordination between the two. Emphasis is on the ability to resolve and employ
various building elements as informed by design intent, aesthetics, functionality and sustainability thematics
through studio-based exercises and precedent studies. This course is educationally sequenced alongside all
other year one session two IA (Hons) courses.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"92e3252bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619cd","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project A","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be asked to complete a series of in class exercises focused on the construction assembly of walls, floors, ceilings, openings, and joinery. The in-class exercises will include a series of technical drawings, and research tasks to summarise the properties and environmental impacts of major material groups used in interior architecture. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9ae3252bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619ce","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"52e3252bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619d3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project B","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Students will be asked to generate a documentation package for a small scale interior. Students must resolve the constructional assembly of building elements specific to the interior, and develop a material palette that is informed by design intent, aesthetics,, functionality and sustainability considerations. The documentation package will include technical drawings and finishes schedules. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9ae3252bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619cd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5ae3252bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619d0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project C: Part 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Project C is an individual task that builds  understanding of typical construction assembly systems in interior architecture.

Through the in class workshops, online activities, course resources and indepdent researc students will learn how typical interior elements, such as walls, floors etc. are constructed.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"92e3252bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619cf","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"62e3252bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619d8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project C: Part 11","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

Project C is an individual task that builds  understanding of typical construction assembly systems in interior architecture.

Through the in class workshops, online activities, course resources and indepdent researc students will learn how typical interior elements, such as walls, floors etc. are constructed.

contentlets.description:
This course focuses on the basic constructional assembly systems and components of interior architectural
building elements. Core considerations include structure, substrate and skin explored in reference to an
introduction to materiality from macro elements to joinery items; building on documentation techniques as a
means of technical communication to industry professionals and the role of the builder versus the role of the
interior architect and the coordination between the two. Emphasis is on the ability to resolve and employ
various building elements as informed by design intent, aesthetics, functionality and sustainability thematics
through studio-based exercises and precedent studies. This course is educationally sequenced alongside all
other year one session two IA (Hons) courses.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"INTA2003 - Interior Architecture Technics 3","description":"

This course focuses on the development of the material and constructional idea of structure, substrate and skin through a focus on the application of materials in conventional and non-conventional details as informed by aesthetics, functionality and environmental sustainability. Core considerations include size, format, edges, junctions and fixings in the constructional and compositional application of materials; the importance of skill as the focus in interior architecture and the role of the interior architect versus the builder/consultant and the coordination between the three. Emphasis is on the documentation of small-scale interior elements and spaces through studio based exercises and precedent studies.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"97e3652bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619dc","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Project B - Summative","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

Project B is an individual exercise which builds upon the knowledge attained in Project A. The project is designed to build a student’s ability to develop and resolve primary edge, junction, fixing and pattern details common to Interior Architecture (CLO1). This project requires students to employ material and detail strategies in an ethical manner, as informed by design intent, aesthetics, functionality and sustainability considerations (CLO2). Students will communicate the resolved constructional details to demonstrate comprehensive documentation skills specific to industry practice in Interior Architecture (CLO3).
The SUMMMATIVE phase will assess the final published version of the response to the brief and the required documentation set.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d3e3652bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d3e3652bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619de","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"dbe3652bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619dd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"17e3652bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619e3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Project A - Formative","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Project A Formative is a individual exercise designed to build student’s ability to identify and resolve primary edge, junction, fixing and pattern details common to Interior Architecture (CLO1). Students will be required to communicate this through a documentation package specific to the practice of interior architecture (CLO3).
The Formative phase will assess the iterative process of producing the required documentation set.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d3e3652bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d3e3652bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619de","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9be3652bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619df","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Project B - Formative","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Project B is an individual exercise which builds upon the knowledge attained in Project A. The project is designed to build a student’s ability to develop and resolve primary edge, junction, fixing and pattern details common to Interior Architecture (CLO1). This project requires students to employ material and detail strategies in an ethical manner, as informed by design intent, aesthetics, functionality and sustainability considerations (CLO2). Students will communicate the resolved constructional details to demonstrate comprehensive documentation skills specific to industry practice in Interior Architecture (CLO3).
The FORMATIVE phase will assess the iterative process of designing to the brief and producing the required documentation set.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d3e3652bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d3e3652bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619de","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"dbe3652bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619dd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9fe3652bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619e7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Project A - Summative","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Project A Summative is a group exercise that amalgamates drawings produced in Project A Formative into a cohesive documentation set of industry standards. The final drawing set is designed to solidify a student’s ability to identify and resolve primary edge, junction, fixing and pattern details common to Interior Architecture as well as coordinate and connect the representation of detailing between drawing types (CLO1). Students will be required to communicate this through a documentation package specific to the practice of interior architecture (CLO3).
The Summative phase will assess the final published version of the documentation set.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d3e3652bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d3e3652bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619de","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d7e3652bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619ec","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/INTA2003.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"INTA2004 - Interior Architecture Technics 4","description":"

This course focuses on the systems of interior architecture environmental controls including, lighting, acoustics, thermal comfort and building services. Core considerations include natural and artificial lighting principles and design considerations; acoustics and noise control principles and design considerations with focus on material selection and spatial geometry; exploration of passive design and conventional/alternative energy sources for human thermal comfort and overview of building services documentation including mechanical services, hydraulic services, electrical services, telecommunications and fire protection systems with a focus on coordination with consultants. Emphasis is on the understanding of interior architectural environmental control through studio based exercises and precedent studies. This course is educationally sequenced alongside all other year two session two BIA (Hons) courses.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"50f3a52bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619f3","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 03","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

Students will be asked to detail the interior environmental system components of an interior project. Students must propose a lighting scheme, thermal comfort, acoustic and building services strategy in a manner that is technically accurate, functional, environmentally responsible, socially responsible, aesthetically pleasing, and response to design intent. Students must communicate their scheme through a comprehensive technical documentation package. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"58f3a52bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619f3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"58f3a52bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619f4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"10f3a52bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619f9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 02","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"45","description":"

This is an individual exercise designed to build a student’s ability to identify the basic technical principles of natural lighting, artificial lighting,thermal comfort and acoustics specific to interior architecture and develop an understanding of how these elements have been employed in a design scheme.

 

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"50f3a52bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619f4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"18f3a52bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619f6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 01","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be asked to complete a light study on an existing building. Students must identify and analyse the basic technical principles of natural and artificial lighting.

contentlets.description:
This course sets the foundation for the thinking and practice of interior architecture as a distinctive idea-led field of design inquiry.

The Design component introduces students to the processes, materiality and elements of interior architecture. The Communication component introduces students to a range of techniques and applications for representing space, including basic analogue and digital drawing and model making.  Emphasis is placed on an expansive approach to spatial enquiry, underpinned by thoughtful and self-reflective research.
contentlets.title: Design Practice 1: Enquire

The Design component introduces students to languages and elements of spatial enclosure and definition, including issues of materiality and assemblage, human scale and form, in relation to simple forms of occupation.  The Communication component introduces students to a range of techniques and applications for representing spatial atmosphere and effect, including advanced analogue and digital drawing and model making.  Emphasis is placed on an expansive approach to spatial articulation underpinned by thoughtful and self-reflective research.

contentlets.description:
This course focuses on the articulation of design ideas through thinking, drawing and making practices.

The Design component introduces students to languages and elements of spatial enclosure and definition, including issues of materiality and assemblage, human scale and form, in relation to simple forms of occupation.  The Communication component introduces students to a range of techniques and applications for representing spatial atmosphere and effect, including advanced analogue and digital drawing and model making.  Emphasis is placed on an expansive approach to spatial articulation underpinned by thoughtful and self-reflective research.
contentlets.title: Design Practice 2: Articulate

This course focuses on the translation of design ideas through multiple and interactive design practices.


The Design component focuses on the language and elements of spatial dynamics, including issues of spatial and material relationships and sequence in relation to multiple forms of occupation, including retail and hospitality typologies. The Communication component focuses on a range of techniques and applications for representing spatial thinking, including generative, illustrative, observational and analytical tools.  Emphasis is placed on an expansive approach to spatial translation underpinned by thoughtful and self-reflective research.

contentlets.description:
This course focuses on the translation of design ideas through multiple and interactive design practices.

The Design component focuses on the language and elements of spatial dynamics, including issues of spatial and material relationships and sequence in relation to multiple forms of occupation, including retail and hospitality typologies. The Communication component focuses on a range of techniques and applications for representing spatial thinking, including generative, illustrative, observational and analytical tools.  Emphasis is placed on an expansive approach to spatial translation underpinned by thoughtful and self-reflective research.

This course focuses on the development of spatial creativity through informed experimental design practices.


The Design component focuses on the languages and elements of spatial organisation, from idea to material detail in relation to complex forms and patterns of occupation including workplace and institutional typologies. The Communication component focuses on a range of  techniques and applications for representing spatial experimentation, including innovative digital technologies.

A personal design portfolio forms part of this course, and a satisfactory portfolio is a requirement for progression into the final two years of the Program.

Design Practice 5: Narrate","description":"

This course focuses on the development and realization of interior spatial narratives through research-led design practice.  Emphasis is placed on the integration of design and professional practice through projects focussed on complex forms and patterns of occupation in small to medium scale buildings. Students are introduced to fundamental elements of current business practices and the information and knowledge required to comprehend the practices, processes and procedures within the profession of interior architecture.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"INTA2411 - Dissertation","description":"

The dissertation is to be a written work of scholarship of between 6,000 and 8,000 words that deals with the theoretical basis of the student's proposed Graduation Project – or a topic of their choice. It will demonstrate the student's ability to thoroughly research an approved topic and present a well-reasoned argument in support of a clearly stated hypothesis. It is to be completed before the commencement of the Graduation Project.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ec042d2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619ee","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Dissertation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"100","description":"

The main assessment task is the final submission, worth 100% Within the final submission there are three criteria of assessment:

• Quality of research and its relationship to design practice
• Quality of argument in relation to design practice
• Clarity of expression

\n

Progress work will be assessed according to rubric across 5 individual meetings with the supervisor.

\n

The assessor marking the dissertations will consider all three criteria when completing the ‘Assessment Sheet’ and allocating marks.

of Arts, Design and Architecture","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"INTA3000 - Interior Architecture Practice Studio 3","description":"

This course focuses on the translation of Interior architectural research, thinking and ideas through multiple and iterative design practices. Design language and elements of spatial dynamics, including spatial and material relationships and sequence in relation to multiple forms of occupation, including retail and hospitality typologies are a focus of this studio. Emphasis is placed on an expansive approach to spatial translation underpinned by thoughtful and self-reflective research. This course is educationally sequenced alongside all other year two term one BIA (Hons) courses.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"867eb08cdb123050595850d8f49619b9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design Resolution (Project B)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

This submission showcases the student's resolved design solution to the brief for Project B, within the context of the site(s). The assessment is reflective of an external pitch so students must clearly and effectively communicate their ideas using enticing visual, written and/or verbal communication. All elements of this submission are a final iteration of work produced for previous Design Development tasks and must reflect the interpretation of feedback received during studio and work(out)shops from tutors, peer demonstrators and peers.

This submission showcases the student's resolved design solution to the brief for Project A, within the context of the site(s). The assessment is reflective of an external pitch so students must clearly and effectively communicate their ideas using enticing visual, written and/or verbal communication. All elements of this submission are a final iteration of work produced for previous Design Development tasks and must reflect the interpretation of feedback received during studio and work(out)shops from tutors, peer demonstrators and peers.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ce7eb08cdb123050595850d8f49619ba","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d27eb08cdb123050595850d8f49619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"da7eb08cdb123050595850d8f49619bb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"da7eb08cdb123050595850d8f49619bc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"967eb08cdb123050595850d8f49619d2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design Development (Projects A + B)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

A series of low-stakes progress presentations to support students in the iterative process, the translation of strategic ideas into spatial outcomes, and provide feedback on progress. The output of these presentations is the first iteration of part of the design solution for Project A and B (as per briefs). The presentations are reflective of an in-house presentation, meaning the priority is clear and effective communication of idea, intentions and draft solutions.

Students will be introduced to methods of research, analysis, interpretation and documentation within the context of academic conventions and in relation to the development of design propositions.

A written analysis, designed to develop fundamental skills in description, analysis and critique, that relates to a specific site (visited in class) and structured under a number of given headings.

Feedback to students will be provided as part of the tutorial conversation and as denoted by a specific course Rubric for all assignments in this course. Feedback sheets designed for each assessment component will also be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d5046d2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619ed","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d5046d2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619ee","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"dd046d2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619ec","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"dd046d2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619ed","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"19046d2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619f0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design Research Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Each student to deliver a visual and oral presentation, accompanied by a summary written statement, that demonstrates the ways in which research has informed the concept and design elements of their studio design. 

Feedback to students will be provided as part of the tutorial conversation and as denoted by a specific course Rubric for all assignments in this course. Feedback sheets designed for each assessment component will also be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d5046d2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619ed","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d5046d2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619ee","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"dd046d2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619ec","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"dd046d2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619ed","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"21046d2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619fc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Structured Analysis Research","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

A research component aimed to develop the students’ skills in academic research, that serves as a preparatory exercise for the Structured Written Analysis. 

Feedback to students will be provided as part of the tutorial conversation and as denoted by a specific course Rubric for all assignments in this course. Feedback sheets designed for each assessment component will also be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d5046d2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619ed","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d5046d2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619ee","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"dd046d2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619ec","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"dd046d2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619ed","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"95046d2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619f6","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/INTA3001.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}
contentlets.description: This course sets the foundation for thinking about interior space within historical, cultural and theoretical contexts. Students will be introduced to methods of research, analysis, interpretation and documentation within the context of academic conventions and in relation to the development of design propositions.
contentlets.title: Interior Architecture Critical Perspectives 1

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"INTA3002 - Interior Architecture Critical Perspectives 2","description":"

Critical Perspectives 2 builds on your foundational study in History of Design Thinking. The course focuses on interior space as a site of dwelling and introduces you to historical, cultural and theoretical perspectives on the concept of dwelling and its material constructions.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c204ad2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619b3","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1 - Case Study","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This assessment requires you to research one case study from the periods that have been covered in the course to date. 

This task aims to develop your skills in academic research, locating, analysing and referencing academic sources, and thoughtfully curating research to form an argument. It requires you to develop and understanding of historical approaches to interiors in their relevant contexts.

Feedback on individual assessments will be delivered via Moodle and general feedback in-class by the tutor. 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c204ad2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c204ad2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ca04ad2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619b4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1a04ad2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619bc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Engagement portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

The engagment portfolio is a series of tasks that demonstrate your engagement with the learning content and activites of the course. These take the form of responding to the readings, quizzes, satisfactory engagement in the tutorial exercises and evidence of peer collaboration. 

Aims: This task aims to develop your ability to engage with content, learning and peers, as well as repsonding to the ideas of others and communicate your thoughts and position in relation to the content presented in the course.

General feeback is provided in-class as well as in Moodle for specific items of the portfolio. 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c204ad2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c204ad2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ca04ad2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ca04ad2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619b4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5204ad2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619c1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2 - Critical Analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

 This assessment requires you to document and then analyse your current dwelling in light of the ideas, theories and precedents studied throughout the course. This assessment takes the form of a written and graphic analysis as well as an in-class presentatino. 

This task aims to develop your ability to place and communicate your own work in a critical, historical design context. It requires you to trace the influences of historical interior practices and theory on your own design thinking.

Feedback on individual assessments will be delivered via Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c204ad2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c204ad2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ca04ad2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ca04ad2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619b4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8a04ad2bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619b6","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/INTA3002.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

The course focuses on interior space as a site of dwelling and introduces you to historical, cultural and theoretical perspectives on the concept of dwelling and its material constructions.

Critical Perspectives 4 builds on your previous studies in History of Design Thinking and the other courses in the Critical Perspectives stream. This course focuses on interior space as a site of constructed identity. The role of interior architecture in codifying and reproducing social identities will be explored through an historical, cultural and theoretical investigation of a range of typologies including civic, community and corporate.


This course also provides the basis for further independent research in BENV4000 (Research Methods) and INTA2411 Dissertation (Interiors)

contentlets.keywords: interior architecture,constructed identity,social identity,history,theory,culture,civic environments,corporate environments
contentlets.description:
Critical Perspectives 4 builds on your previous studies in History of Design Thinking and the other courses in the Critical Perspectives stream. This course focuses on interior space as a site of constructed identity. The role of interior architecture in codifying and reproducing social identities will be explored through an historical, cultural and theoretical investigation of a range of typologies including civic, community and corporate.

This course also provides the basis for further independent research in BENV4000 (Research Methods) and INTA2411 Dissertation (Interiors)
contentlets.title: Interior Architecture Critical Perspectives 4

Architecture Practice Studio 4","description":"

 


This course focuses on the development of spatial creativity through informed Interior Architectural design practices. Student learning will focus on the languages and elements of spatial organisation, from research and idea to material detail in relation to complex forms and patterns of occupation including workplace and institutional typologies. This course is educationally sequenced alongside all other year two session two BIA (Hons) courses.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"INTA4004 - Practice of Interior Architecture","description":"

This course presents fundamental elements of current 'best' business practices from the profession of Interior Architecture. Scholarly links are fostered within flipped lecture based setting around the activities of design practice contexts and the profession of interior architecture. These professional skills provide students with information and knowledge required to comprehend  and engage with the practices, processes and procedures within the profession of interior architecture. Professional responsibilities and associated legal contexts, governmental procedures and policy, professional imperatives and priorities are examined and explored within the context of Interior Architectural Practice.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7414616bdb21fc50be4672f5f396196b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"ASSIGNMENT 4: Professionally Manage The Compliance Process (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Successfully delivering a built interior relies on effective management of the compliance process. This task guides you in facilitating your project’s smooth passage thru the Council compliance processes, ie without the pain of costly ongoing Council-ordered rectifications. Repeat this mantra: “The Certifier is my friend. I need to keep my Certifier happy. The Certifier is my friend…”

Students will be assessed as individuals.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7414616bdb21fc50be4672f5f396196c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7414616bdb21fc50be4672f5f396196d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0514616bdb21fc50be4672f5f396197a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"ASSIGNMENT 2: Set Up Your Project for Success (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Setting up a client relationship for success means professionally managing your client’s expectations of the project, its processes and your respective responsibilities. With this task you will learn to prepare professional fee proposals and negotiate clear, effective + equitable contracts built to future proof your relationship and manage project risk.

Students will be assessed as individuals.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7414616bdb21fc50be4672f5f396196c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7c14616bdb21fc50be4672f5f396196b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7c14616bdb21fc50be4672f5f396196c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7014616bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961972","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"ASSIGNMENT 1: Create a Powerful Portfolio (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Your portfolio is a crucial tool for communicating your professional capabilities. This task aims to develop your skills in curating and communicating your professional capabilities to prospective employers, clients and other stakeholders using both online and physical delivery. Emphasis will be placed on compellingly communicating your unique professional capabilities and professional core values.

Students will be assessed as individuals.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7c14616bdb21fc50be4672f5f396196b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7c14616bdb21fc50be4672f5f396196c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f414616bdb21fc50be4672f5f396196e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"ASSIGNMENT 3: Master The Pre Design Process","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

This task reinforces the importance of professionally managing your client’s expectations of the project, its processes and your respective responsibilities. Here you will learn how to uncover your client’s hidden needs; prepare effective client return briefs; how to assemble an effective team of Council compliance experts; and how to professionally navigate the regulatory compliance process.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7414616bdb21fc50be4672f5f396196c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7414616bdb21fc50be4672f5f396196d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f814616bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961976","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/INTA4004.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}
contentlets.description: This course presents fundamental elements of current 'best' business practices from the profession of Interior Architecture. Scholarly links are fostered within flipped lecture based setting around the activities of design practice contexts and the profession of interior architecture. These professional skills provide students with information and knowledge required to comprehend  and engage with the practices, processes and procedures within the profession of interior architecture. Professional responsibilities and associated legal contexts, governmental procedures and policy, professional imperatives and priorities are examined and explored within the context of Interior Architectural Practice.
contentlets.title: Practice of Interior Architecture

contentlets.keywords: interior architecture,industry and professional practice,research,design resolution,communication,design project,interior architecture design  studio
contentlets.description: This course focuses on the development and realization of interior spatial narratives through research-led design practice. Emphasis is placed on the integration of design and professional practice through projects focused on complex forms and patterns of occupation in small to medium scale buildings.
contentlets.title: Interior Architecture Practice Studio 5

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"INTA6000 - Interior Architecture Practice Studio 6","description":"

This course focuses on the development and realization of interior spatial transformations through research-led design practice.  Emphasis is placed on the integration of design and professional practice through projects focussed on complex forms and patterns of occupation in medium to large scale buildings. Students are introduced to fundamental elements of current business practices and the information and knowledge required to comprehend the practices, processes and procedures within the profession of interior architecture.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4a14a16bdb21fc50be4672f5f396197e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Strategic Design Sign Off","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Your client has approved your strategic design direction and you are now asked to resolve and present the final
design outcome. In addition to the overall workplace, you need to select 3 key spaces to detail for this:
‐ The Individual workspace and associated workpoints
‐ 2 x other spaces showing different work modes (i.e., collaborate + innovate, meeting, present + publish,
Skunkworks, connect + network, etc)
This is a formal online graphic and verbal presentation of your strategic design solution to the client.
Minimum Assessment Requirements
‐ Plans and sections as necessary to communicate the whole overall design and its Kit of Parts at 1:100
scale
‐ 3D model representation showing your overall design insertion within the existing building shell. All levels should be shown to demonstrate how you have resolved the connectivity, adjacency and interactions with the existing architecture. This
can be presented in any format you chose (i.e., exploded axonometrics, animations, fly through or walk
through, live tour within the 3D model as you present)
‐ Perspectives as necessary to communicate the overall strategic design within the site context
(insertion, forms, relationships and dialogue). Minimum 3 perspectives in total
‐ Diagrams, plans, sections, elevations, perspectives and / or models to communicate the detailed design
of your 3 keyspaces, how they are used and their role in the Kit of Parts at a minimum scale of 1:50
‐ Details (1 x minimum) at 1:10/1:5 scale from each detailed space (3 in total)
‐ Materials palette and sensory data sheet for each keyspace
Except where stated otherwise in the requirements above, the format and medium of the presentation is
entirely up to you.
This presentation must communicate your whole design narrative, including reference to all previous phases
completed where relevant ‐ how your design resolution fits into the overarching strategy proposed in
Assessment 01 and the detail resolution of spaces in relation to this and your development of the Kit of Parts.
Students must demonstrate aptitude in sectional design and feasible linkages between floors.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0214a16bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0214a16bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961981","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0614a16bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961998","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Return Brief (Group + Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Your firm has been short‐listed as one of 6. Your Client has asked you to submit a proposal for the new Research Incubator in the form of a Return Brief which will be presented as both a design Pitch presentation and written submission. The proposal must showcase your unique approach to the client, site and brief.
Each firm (team) has been allocated 15 minutes for their pitch presentations including client (tutor) feedback.
Minimum Assessment Requirements
‐ this assessment is to be completed in teams of 3 or 4 students.
‐ this assessment is comprised of 2 parts – 01A (Pitch Presentation) and 01B (Written submission) – minimum requirements for both must be delivered in order to gain a pass. All components within the two parts are to be completed collaboratively by the team, except for the form explorations, volumetric gesture, overall project focus lens and materiality mood board. This distinction has been made to reflect standard industry practice of providing a client with multiple design directions, and also to support your transition into individual work for assessment 02.
‐ CAD files of the base building floor plans and a SketchUp building shell model have been provided to you; however, individuals must build their own insertions to be shown as options during the pitch presentation.
‐ Student names and Numbers must be clearly visible in both parts.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0214a16bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961981","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0a14a16bdb21fc50be4672f5f396197f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0a14a16bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961980","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8a14a16bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961993","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Engagement Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

The Engagement Portfolio is comprised of 2 parts:
PART 1: Weekly Online Lesson modules – 10% Pass/Fail
[Pass = all modules have been completed / Fail = not all modules have been completed]
This is a series of 12 online lesson modules have been designed to replace traditional face to face lectures each
week. All of the course content, theory and resources are contained within therefore allowing students to listen,
absorb, re‐visit when required and learn at their own pace throughout the weeks.
Engagement with these modules is essential to successful progress in this course. The subsequent Engagement
Portfolio tasks cannot be submitted until that weeks’ modules are marked as ‘complete’ (i.e. watched and
completed in full), so it is essential that you engage regularly to avoid falling behind.

\n

PART 2: Engagement Portfolio Tasks – 20% Pass/Fail
This series of process activities is designed to be completed before, during and after studio tutorial time
throughout the Term to help you progress towards the formal assessment milestones and apply the theoretical
learning from the online lesson modules.
Each task will vary in focus and format, aligned to the topics covered and project focus that week. Details for all
tasks are available under the relevant weeks in Moodle. A breakdown of tasks, weightings and dates is as
follows:
‐ Week 1: Site analysis diagrams + Company Profile [1%]
‐ Week 2: Synthesised strategic research, User and workstyles list [1%]
‐ Week 3: Pitch presentation content and layout (WIP) [1%] + Toolkit collage, zoning + adjacency
diagrams WIP [1%]
‐ Week 5: Kit of Parts matrix and speculative diagrams [1%] + 1:100 Plan and Section progress [1%]
‐ Week 7: 1:100 Plan and Section developed [10%] + Technology matrix and speculative diagrams [1%] +
Wireframe sketch development [1%]
‐ Week 8: Materials sensory matrixes [1%] + Rendered perspectives WIP with materials [1%]

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0214a16bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0214a16bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961981","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0a14a16bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961980","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c614a16bdb21fc50be4672f5f3961982","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/INTA6000.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"INTA7000 - Interior Architecture Practice Studio 7","description":"

Year 4 design studio focuses on the agency of the interior within the context of the urban morphologies and civic typologies of the twenty-first century city. As the culminating student experience of the BIA, the studios will act as an environment in which the knowledge and skills acquired over the previous 3 years can be synthesised, refined and communicated with proficiency, over a 20 week project development, mirroring the processes, products and dispositions of a professional design practice.

Design Practice 7 - Propose incorporates a research phase and its translation into a design proposition. The research phase will comprise of site, heritage and context analysis, which will inform the development of the student’s brief for the project in the form of a Design Research Report and Project Brief. Using the report and brief as the research underpinning, students will then propose an initial design response in the form of a primary spatial move. The outcome from this studio is the design research, design brief and design proposition that will form the basis of the final design studio, Design Practice 8 – Resolve.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"INTA8000 - Interior Architecture Practice Studio 8","description":"

This course focuses on the second phase of detailed design and resolution of the final design project, culminating in a cohesive and comprehensive design response.


This studio builds on the design propositions developed in Design Practice 7: Propose. Using the design proposition developed in the Investigation phase, students will then work on detailed design development and resolution of a number of key spaces and elements within the scheme, incorporating work from all phases in a final presentation. The outcome from this studio is a rigorous, inventive and professional design proposal which includes documentation of design research, design process and the developed design.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f714256bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619c2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Design Development","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Assessment 1 asks you to demonstrate control of the large-scale aspects of your graduation project and development of the room-scale interior spaces, communicated through large-scale drawings, graphic storyboard, and verbal presentation. Part of your mark will involve peer evaluation of collaboration skills.

\n

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"3714256bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3714256bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619c4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3714256bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3f14256bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3f14256bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619c4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7714256bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619ca","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Design Resolution and Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Assessment 2 is the final ‘pitch’ to the client, stakeholders, and design community, via graphic and verbal presentation.
It also includes the reflective phase of the design process, an opportunity to reflect on your learning, via narrative description.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"3714256bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3714256bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619c4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3714256bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3f14256bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3f14256bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619c4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c024256bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619d1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Engagement Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Assessment 3 comprises a collection of weekly formative tasks undertaken over the semester. It is a means of developing and capturing skills in iterative and reflective design thinking and making.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"3714256bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3714256bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619c5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"fb14256bdb21fc50be4672f5f39619c6","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/INTA8000.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

This course focuses on the second phase of detailed design and resolution of the final design project, culminating in a cohesive and comprehensive design response.

This studio builds on the design propositions developed in Design Practice 7: Propose. Using the design proposition developed in the Investigation phase, students will then work on detailed design development and resolution of a number of key spaces and elements within the scheme, incorporating work from all phases in a final presentation. The outcome from this studio is a rigorous, inventive and professional design proposal which includes documentation of design research, design process and the developed design.
